editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msDesc.head: HUGH OF FLEURY, BEDE; S. XII 3/4

msItem.author: HUGH OF FLEURY
msItem.title: Historia Ecclesiastica
msItem.incipit: Assiriorum igitur potentissimus fuit olim rex Ninus
msItem.note: The common second edition of 1110 in six books, of which extracts were printed by G. Waitz in MGH Scriptores 9. 337–64 (= PL 163. 830–54); see A. Vidier, L’historiographie à Saint-Benoît-sur-Loire et les miracles de Saint Benoît (Paris, 1965), pp. 77–8; N. Lettinck in Stegmüller, Bibl. 91 (1981), 386–97. Often attrib., as here, to its dedicatee, Ivo of Chartres.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Chronicon
msItem.incipit: Adam annorum centum triginta genuit Seth

msItem.title: The acts of III Lateran Council (1179)
msItem.incipit: Licet de uitanda discordia in electione Romani pontificis
msItem.explicit: Si quis uero receperit et ecclesie non reddiderit Christiana sepultura priuetur.
msItem.note: J. D. Mansi, Sacrorum Conciliorum nova et amplissima Collectio (Florence, 1759-), 22. 217–27, in the order cc. 1–3, 27, 19, 22, 21, 20, 7, 10, 18, 4, 6, 8, 16, 11–12, 15, 9, 23, 25,17, 14 (from ‘Prohibemus ne laici decimas cum animarum suarum periculo detinentes’).

supportDesc.extent:
126 leaves (i + 125) 285 185
200 120
The edges heavily retrimmed and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: 16 + a bifolium (two half-leaves), 2–1010, 116; in the middle of this quire are inserted 128 and 1314. Art. 1 ends with quire 10.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with crayon in 2 cols of 32 lines. Not pricked in the inner margins. Running heads on ruled lines only a col. wide.

handDesc.handNote: Written throughout in a single practised protogothic bookhand of English appearance; flex punctuation.
Fols. 121v-3 in an English hand little later than the main text.

decoDesc.decoNote: On fol. 1 is a red initial, arabesqued in green, blue and buff. The other books of art. 1 open with handsome decorated initials outlined in ink of text, washed in blue and green (sometimes yellow), associated with red and green display script. Art. 2 opens with an initial of this type, with red and blue display script; otherwise initials in blue, red, or green, sometimes ornamented in a second colour. Scarcely any green is used after fol. 101.
Fols. 123v-5v are blank but for a crude unfinished pencil sketch of a man on fol. 124, perhaps of s. xiii.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii; sewn on four bands; formerly chained from the usual position. Fols. i and 125 were pastedowns in an earlier binding. At the foot of the foredge of fol. i, cropped by the binder, is the mark of a brass chain-staple. On fol. 125 are marks of a brass strap-pin and of the large iron chain-staple.

history.provenance: Made in England, perhaps at a Cistercian house.
On fol. 124 is an erased inscription.

At the head of fol. 1 is ‘liber domus scolarium de Mertone in Oxonia ex legat’ M. Ioh’ Raynham sacre pagine professoris et quondam socii eiusdem domus cuius anime propicietur Deus amen.’ For Reynham, d. 1376, see MS 18.

Inside the front board are ‘N. 7. 8. Art:’ (canc. in red), and a brief table of contents, both s. xvii; on a slip of paper, ‘B. 1. 11’ (in red), and ‘Merton Coll. MS. 88’ in purple; the College bookplate.
At the head of fol. 1 is the James no. ‘51’ (recte 52), s. xvii in. ‘8’ (perhaps changed from ‘4’) is inked on the foredge.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Coxe, p. 47; Powicke, no. 348; Alexander & Temple, no. 80.
